data: At the foot of the hill on which stands the Campidoglio at Rome, and close beneath the ruins that now encumber the Tarpeian rock, runs a mean-looking alley, called the Viccolo D’Orsi, but better known to the police as the ‘Viccolo dei Ladri,’ or ‘Thieves’ Corner’—the epithet being, it is said, conferred in a spirit the very reverse of calumnious.

foot of the hill | Campidoglio | Rome | Tarpeian rock | Viccolo D’Orsi | Viccolo dei Ladri | Thieves’ Corner

At the foot of the hill on which stands the Campidoglio at Rome, and close beneath the ruins that now encumber the Tarpeian rock, runs a mean-looking alley, called the Viccolo D’Orsi, but better known to the police as the ‘Viccolo dei Ladri,’ or ‘Thieves’ Corner’--the epithet being, it is said, conferred in a spirit the very reverse of calumnious.
Gerald Fitzgerald, the Chevalier: A Novel
Lever, Charles James, 1806-1872; McCormick, A. D. (Arthur David), 1860-1943 [Illustrator]
